body:
You can use XSeg to create a model that will suit your purposes. XSeg is more advanced and I promise you'll find it far easier and more accurate when it comes to manual masking. I need a general masking model as well, so what I did is grab a medium sample of my alignments from multiple sources and manually masked them. Then you can train the model and apply it to non-masked alignments. Any that are not successful you can edit and then add to your training set. In this way, you'll be able to get a generalized model from XSeg that, while it won't be as good as a specific model to your project, will still be better than the FANSeg model would be and future editing and improvement will be significantly easier. Workflow breakdown below:

1. Grab 10-20 alignments from each dst/src you have, while ensuring they vary and try not to go higher than ~150 at first.

2. Manually mask these with XSeg

3. Train XSeg on these masks

4. Apply the XSeg model to ~100 more alignments that you haven't used yet and vary widely

5. Manually fix any that are not masked properly and then add those to the training set

6. Repeat steps 3-5 until you have no incorrect masks on step 4.

> You can use XSeg to create a model that will suit your purposes. XSeg is more advanced and I promise you'll find it far easier and more accurate when it comes to manual masking. I need a general masking model as well, so what I did is grab a medium sample of my alignments from multiple sources and manually masked them. Then you can train the model and apply it to non-masked alignments. Any that are not successful you can edit and then add to your training set. In this way, you'll be able to get a generalized model from XSeg that, while it won't be as good as a specific model to your project, will still be better than the FANSeg model would be and future editing and improvement will be significantly easier. Workflow breakdown below:
> 
> 1. Grab 10-20 alignments from each dst/src you have, while ensuring they vary and try not to go higher than ~150 at first.
> 2. Manually mask these with XSeg
> 3. Train XSeg on these masks

> 5. Manually fix any that are not masked properly and then add those to the training set
> 6. Repeat steps 3-5 until you have no incorrect masks on step 4.

THANKS "GENIUS", I KNOW HOW TO USE XSEG.
FOR MAKING A SMALL PROTOTYPE VIDEOS FANSEG IS SO USEFUL, LATER I CAN USE XSEG IF THE RESULTS ARE GOOD.
THE PROBLEM IS I HAVE TO MAINTAIN TWO VERSIONS OF DFL TO USE FANSEG AND NEW XSEG,
THAT'S WHY I'M REQUESTING TO BRING BACK FANSEG IN NEWER VERSIONS.
IT WOULD BE SO USEFUL TO MAKE PROTOTYPES AND SAVES HOURS OF MASKING TIME AND DAYS OF TRAINING TIME.

Well luckily for you, you don't have to maintain two versions. Only the XSeg version will be updated and, if your laziness isn't to such an extreme, you can copy the FANSeg functionality into the new folder thus having access to both.

But, I'm curious. DO you know how to use XSeg? It doesn't seem like it if you are estimating hours of masking and days of training. I spent about an hour masking and maybe 3 training and already have a more powerful XSeg than the most recent FANSeg. If you really did know how it worked you'd realize how quickly you'd make up for your "lost time" in future masking efficiency.

Or, obviously, you can just continue on being the smartest man in the world and a dick to people taking their time to try to help you and keep wondering why nothing in your life is as easy as you so very much deserve it to be.

> Well luckily for you, you don't have to maintain two versions. Only the XSeg version will be updated and, if your laziness isn't to such an extreme, you can copy the FANSeg functionality into the new folder thus having access to both.

""" you can copy the FANSeg functionality into the new folder thus having access to both.""" WTF??
OH GENIUS HOW CAN YOU BE SO DUMB? 
IT DOESN'T WORK LIKE THAT GENIUS

I mean...I did it. Idk, maybe you aren't being sarcastic and I actually am a genius. But I'd think it more likely to be the case that you are simply the opposite. I'm not going to assist you any further. You're on your own, bud. Good luck.

> I mean...I did it. Idk, maybe you aren't being sarcastic and I actually am a genius. But I'd think it more likely to be the case that you are simply the opposite. I'm not going to assist you any further. You're on your own, bud. Good luck.

I DON'T NEED DUMB ASSISTANCE GENIUS AND I'M BEING SARCASTIC SO DON'T WORRY YOU ARE NOT A GENIUS

A heck of a lot of rudeness on both sides going on in this thread.. 

First of all to @The-Digital-Void  No, it's not as easy as copying fanseg over, there's a number of code mods you have to make, and you can't just copy the code from the older install and paste it into the new scripts.. the structure has changed enough that you have to understand python to do it.  TBH you make it sound like you just dropped it in and like magic, it worked.. that's simply not the case..  I've managed to get it mostly working but I just don't have the time to dedicate to it, I've been a coder for 22 years.. he has a valid question/request.. I happen to agree that it would be nice to have it back and I do in fact maintain two versions for now but I know that won't be feasible for long.  It's not about lazy, it's about optimizing my time, convenience, and also the mere fact that fanseg works pretty effectively as is.  What would be great is to make these models more modular, a great system would be one where you could download DFL core and then download the rest as plugins..   Bottom line though, just because you prefer xseg doesn't mean everyone does, and just because others prefer fanseg doesn't mean you do.. it's that simple.  So no need for anyone to insult others.

Secondly I agree that fanseg would be nice to have back, it works pretty well and it's hands off almost every time, no need to manually draw a mask unless you're doing something more complex, I am quite familiar with xseg.. I would still prefer having the option, as would a lot of others.. I've seen it come up in questions on forums and now here..  no need to be mean about it.. 

@rlkiran seriously, no need for all caps yelling and cussing.. really not necessary at all.. You're not going to get any help if your going to respond in that way, trust me.

> PLEASE BRING BACK FANSEG MASKING FOR HOURS IS NOT WORTHY FOR SOME VIDEOS PLEASE BRING BACK FANSEG

I will point out that you don't have to manually mask every single frame, often you can get away with a dozen or so, it depends on what you're doing..  it will learn from what you do mask out and it's good enough to know how to carry that forward.

However.. there's no QUESTION it's more time consuming because you'll sometimes render everything out only to find out you have more work to do.. but it does work well if you have the time to put in.

Not everyone does.. when I DO have the time I would prefer xseg, when I don't, I would prefer fanseg.. it works very well with no manual masking at all.. I haven't really had an experience of it failing me.

I suppose bringing back FANSeg wouldn’t really hurt, but XSeg is a substantially more powerful tool for a relatively low time investment.  Adding the option might not be bad, but we should encourage the use of XSeg whenever possible.

I contend that XSeg is more robust than the people in this thread are making it out to be.  Very rarely will you need to spend more than an hour masking the destination faceset, and fixing isolated buggy frames by simply masking a couple of them isn’t too time-consuming either.  While I understand FANSeg was quite convenient, I still maintain that XSeg is miles better than what FANSeg could ever offer.  However, I suppose bringing back the option might not hurt.

@TalosOfCrete 

Not at all denying that xseg is more powerful, it's more robust and quite capable.. it's less convenient to certain workflows and timeconstraints though, and I think that .. as you said.. it can't hurt to have fanseg as an option..  I do have it working now, but it was some effort to get integrated back in.. works well however..

Just sometimes it would be perfectly ok to use and would save a lot of time, especially when working on a time budget for a project... Maybe we can get iperov to build in a plugin system where we can add it in if we want it.. or not.. :) someone else could maintain it that part of it so he doesn't have to.. but it works quite well honestly.

PS. Thanks for engaging politely..  some people on here can be... less than nice :)

@oneduality Alright, you make a fair point.  Perhaps you could fork DFL with this working integrated FANSeg and drop a pull request?  You make valid points about time constraints, and merely leaving it there (so long as the use of XSeg is encouraged above FANSeg, as the former is resoundingly more robust and capable than the latter) should not be an issue.

I actually wanted XSEG back pretty bad until this rlkiran acted out like a
little petulant child.  Now I'd rather they don't bring it back on
principle.
